Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

I spent no hours per week on this course. Reason being I wasn't able to attend very many except for the Saturday session, which I found to be very helpful and useful for the future.
really depend on yourself. but if you want to practice more, you can make appointment with instructors and they would very willing to help you
10 hours
1-2 hours per week to polish my resume and improve my interview skills. Schedule appointments with instructors for advice.

Very useful

not a weekly commitment - I do wish there were more/different time opportunities. Since the PSS tended to be at the same time, it meant that I had very few opportunities to attend.
3 hours for the event
1 hour per week.
I attended both weekend seminars, so I spent 5 hours preparing.

Maybe a few minutes planning which sessions I would attend and some prep work (about an hour or so) for the Saturday sessions.
Less than 1 hour per week
Useful information

- Very good material, insight, and advice
- I wish there had been more events for it this semester

Have sessions that are tailored towards specific fields rather than just generic cover letter advice
Perhaps instead of this requirement since many of us know the info already, make it mandatory for every student to meet with a career counselor for an hour long meeting once a semester

Some seminars were repetitive or too similar to others (resume and cover letter).
Try not to overlap material so much.
Absolutely love this series! I have had many other professional series in the past and this series is by far the most useful!! Unique take on topics and extremely valuable advice!
The skills are very useful and the experience from others helps a lot.
This series is fine, but there should be an option to opt-out of some or all of the requirements depending on how much professional experience a student has before entering YSPH.
good

Strengths = sometimes there was good advice
Weaknesses = sometimes the lectures were longer than they needed to be
I think these sessions are extremely helpful and beneficial for personal growth and career development.
I learned a lot of useful life skills from this series. I wish there were more opportunities throughout the semester since I wasn't able to make it to all.
It's useful and shows students different kinds of knowledge.
I like the menu-style structure, as some sessions were more pertinent than others for me.
Amazing. Continue to do the professional skills series.

The course is helpful in learning about the resources available to us and how we can use them to succeed. I appreciated the help of Kelly and Felicia, as they made the seminars interesting and informative.
I wish there was a "2.0" version of some of the sessions, particularly the resume and cover letter stuff, so people who know what they are doing don't have to sit through the basics.
Strength: It is very helpful for internship and career preparation.
very helpful and interesting
There was no assessment
I really appreciated the accessibility of people from the professional skills series. This has been a very professionally useful course and I think that it should be continued in the future.

Strength: Not many

Weakness: The workshops are not evenly weighted. Good god that Public Speaking with authority hoopla had to have been the biggest waste of my time in my time. You should be awarding credit AND paying people for having to take that god awful thing. You really mean to tell me that waltzing in to a little Cover Letter Session and sitting in the back for 20 minutes is only worth 1/3 of the credits for enduring an entire day of nonesense? I'd urge the YSPH to reevaluate how they award credits!! It is not fair! You should also make zooming in an option or have some way to do make-ups. Like record the session and post a video online with a quiz or something. It shouldn't be this hard NOR should it place such a burden on the students.
Effective for gaining the skills to succeed professionally

A lot of the information is somewhat helpful, but the format of sitting in a classroom for an hour is useless. The same information can be communicated to students that want it by means of documents with the same effectiveness.

Also, as a busy graduate student, the required number of attendances of these seminars is absolutely unnecessary and only serves to create scheduling conflicts.

I really did not enjoy this course. Ethics is a very important concept but I did not feel engaged in the discussions. The content is boring. Additionally, the class times were scheduled at inconvenient times.

I like the credit system- I think it motivates people to take the things that are most useful to them. I did one of the Saturday ones and thought it was worth the time. As someone who has worked for 6 years, I'm not sure most of them are particularly useful for me, but I have the following things I think could be helpful for us older folks:
1. a session towards people who have a career but are switching
2. time management techniques!!!!!!!! These are so useful
3. career mapping (things like purpose now, 5 year, 10 year)
4. I think this is a thing already but salary/benefits negotiation
5. Government jobs- how the "grades" work, benefits and how to enter the system
Its a good course, I couldnt find a database of all the events which would have made planning the semester easier
This course gave me useful skills for public speaking.

Great program design. Please maintain this. 

Sometimes the topics can be facile. I would recommend some outside speakers.
I've really enjoyed the feedback I've received at several events. They have definitely sharpened made my resume and interview skills.

Extremely helpful course! Learned many small details to use when reaching out to alumni or networking with professionals about potential internships and jobs. Also learned about email etiquette, how to fix my resume, and how to write a cover letter.
Workshops are diverse in subjects and very helpful.

Great seminar! I got to learn so much about how to write cover letters, resumes, correspondence emails, as well as perfecting my pitch. I definitely felt like I learned new skills and norms about job hunting. Felicia and Kelly are very professional and attentive - they seem to care about the students' internship and job prospects and they definitely vouch for you.

Found it absolutely useless/meaningful. I understand some students may need this training for being straight out of undergrad but I gained nothing from this course. There are also too many requirements outside of class to make it to 8 sessions. May have been better to structure it for different levels students are in, because I felt so zoned out. It was a huge waste of time, going over extremely basic concepts.
during seminars and workshops I learned a lot, Felicia and Kelly were so helpful whenever I need!

I only attended a few but they were helpful. It is more useful to meet with Kelly or Felicia one on one. It was annoying that the majority of the courses were offered at noon because I work throughout the week and could hardly ever make those times.

Some were not very helpful or were only slightly interesting. The Saturday interview practice was definitely beneficial for getting practice with interview skills and learning about best to say during an interview.
Good. Ethics is basic knowledge in research and study. It is worth to learn.

I can't speak on the skills seminar offered during the week because of conflicting schedules. The Saturday session offered on public speaking helped me to learn how to speak about myself in under 5 minutes. The video recordings will come in handy in the future.

This course is clearly tailored for recent undergraduates with very little to no work experience. As someone who has been working for a few years, I found this course material unhelpful. Additionally, I'm a joint degree with SOM and receive much of my professional services education through the SOM curriculum so I don't think this series added to my knowledge. I suggest removing this requirement for SOM joint degree students since professional development is such a key part of the SOM curriculum.

The professional skills series is generally beneficial, however as a student with work experience after undergrad, I find some of the topic areas to be rudimentary. For me personally, I would have appreciated more sessions dedicated to the summer internship. The one session I attended was very helpful!
I only attended the short sessions. I felt they were concise and gave very concrete advice on how to move forward with whatever process we may be doing (e.g. cover letters, resumes, interviews, etc).
good
I really liked the flexibility of being able to choose which PSS classes to attend.

I think the professional skills course is useful for people who have never worked before. It is not quite as useful for people who came to the MPH from a professional environment. I think people should be able to opt out if they have done the latter. It conflicted with the global health seminar in the evening, so I had to attend the noon ones. And the noon ones conflicted with my actual paying job, forcing me to work later hours to make up for it. The sessions have useful information, but definitely make assumptions about the participants. I appreciate that they are offered, but really don't think they should be mandatory.
The course offered a variety of skills in internship or job hunting, which are all very helpful.
excellent!
good

Strengths: variety of topics
Weaknesses: Inconvenient timings, inconsistent instructions
very useful course. It helped me a lot when looking for internships.

I have enjoyed each of the sessions I have been to so far - they are very helpful! Specifically I really enjoyed the speed interview session. One downside of this course is that it is difficult scheduling-wise. The sessions are offered at inconvenient times.
Pretty great!! Could have more frequent sessions and wish there were more sessions on networking
Great classes, wish more sessions could be held because some of them conflicted with my other classes.
Very useful
Useful for job hunting
Very practical, it helps us a lot in learning the basic sense in our career, and offer us many opportunities to practice.
very good. Skills are extremely helpful

The professional communication focus is very helpful. 

Course construction material   can get repetitive.  

 It might be helpful to give me an outline of what each session teachers, and whether to better assess potential for learning new material before attending each session.

This series is great for younger students who may not have a lot of work experience - however, I don't think the topics overall quite apply to folks who already have job experience in different industries. I would love for there to be more variety that could be more geared towards people with more years of experience. Also, need more varied times/sections.

I think this course is geared more towards students with little to no professional experience. As someone with a few years' work experience, I found some of the modules of this course (such as Resume and Cover Letter writing) unhelpful. I think students with a certain amount of outside work experience should be allowed to place out of some or all of the modules in this course. That being said, I thought all of the seminars that included panels with employers, alumni and/or students were generally very informative and helpful.
not very well advertised timings of the class
All of the information provided was too remedial. Clearly geared only towards graduate students who came straight from undergrad with no experience.
Great exposure to different aspects of navigating the job market and working world. Real-world skills that will prove useful.
This was a really great opportunity.
Great workshop! Left with many tangible skills

I was frustrated with the timing of the professional skills seminars because they often overlapped with the required Global Health Seminar. I attended both of the Saturday seminars which were helpful, but I think they should have been worth more credit because the relation of time to credit on the Saturday ones was not the same as the ration of time to credit on the ones during the rest of the week. Also, two of the seminars I had planned to attend were cancelled or moved to a time I could not attend, which was also frustrating.
This course provides me with essential job-hunting skills.

I was a bit skeptical of the session before starting it but I actually found it very helpful. Both the coaches I worked with gave very useful feedback and I liked that they were not trying to impose a certain "style" of speaking as correct but rather helping students improve themselves within their own personal style. The exercises and format of the workshop were also good.
Excellent course! Very helpful!
Would be helpful to have more options are different times.
Really love the course and all of the options it offers. I do wish that so many sessions weren't cancelled or rescheduled, though. That made fulfilling requirements a bit tough.
Its a good course, just the timing conflicted with the global health seminar which was very frustrating.

Overall, the sessions are hit-or-miss. Some of the info provided is extremely basic, but sometimes I learn something I truly didn't know before. Overall, it can feel like a chore to attend some of the sessions, but it also makes sense that not everyone has had the same exposure.

This course is not at all useful for anyone who has worked in a professional setting prior to attending YSPH. The sessions during the week clearly cater to the lowest common denominator and provide rudimentary information for students who do not have experience working in a professional setting. For instance, one session titled, "Navigating the MPH job market" focused entirely on the basics of reading a job posting. While this may have been helpful for a handful of students, the vast majority felt that a much more helpful use of their time for a similar session would be focusing on emerging employment trends for people with MPH degrees. Alternatively, the Saturday sessions were much more helpful because these included tailored one-on-one skill building and coaching. However, it is impractical to ask students to attend lengthy Saturday sessions. Additionally, the required 8 credits for this course seems like a waste of time for most students if the sessions during the week cover only extremely basic employment skills. 

This course might be improved by requiring fewer credits and/or providing some sessions tailored to students who do have professional experience and some for students who do not.

Great way to ensure students gain information about professionalism and the working world. Unfortunately many of the sessions were offered on Thursdays evenings, which clashed with my Global Health Seminar Series
I would want the programming to be more advanced. I understand the basics of writing a resume and cover letter and want that next level of guidance.

I was deeply disappointed by this course. It routinely took away time that would have been better spent studying for my other courses.

I have been in the professional world for a number of years and found all of the "offerings" relevant only to those with little or no work experience. I was particularly disappointed by the "Navigating the MPH Job Market" seminar as it lacked relevant insight into the MPH job market specifically. I found it was more of a "Navigating the Job Market 101" seminar.

In the future it would be beneficial to break students into sub-groups or allow students with significant professional experience to opt out.

The professional skills seminar was often more of a chore than anything, and gave somewhat useful information on occasion. The source of my frustration is the worry that course materials (slides, etc.) will be shared between students who did and did not attend lectures. We are required to attend a certain number of lectures anyway, so I don't understand the emphasis on ensuring that only students who attended a lecture have access to those materials, especially because many of us were enrolled in a class at the same time and were unable to attend. This program is very short, and limiting materials that could have been helpful during the first semester on the premise that they will be available during the second semester seriously handicaps the students applying for internships during the winter break.

- Very knowledgeable, passionate, and helpful
- Sometimes difficult to get in touch with

Professor Vance was excellent at one of the Saturday PSS seminars about interviewing - really sound advice and great tips - day flew by! 

For the other sessions - Kelly and Felicia are FABULOUS! What a pair! Awesome and so very helpful! :)
Good.
good
N/A
Great instructor!
They're great and friendly.
they are wonderful
Not sure who that is
She is extremely profession in this field. Her class is very interesting
Brought up relevant topics and was helpful. It would be better to receive individual feedback to our presentation videos.

I appreciated his contributions over the Saturday course he helped to facilitate during the professional skills series. In this series, we had to design a short (5-min) presentation to discuss our research interests and then were critiqued on public speaking skills. This was very professionally useful and I appreciate everything that he and members of his office did to assist us through this seminar.
Not sure who this is.
William Vance was incredibly helpful during the "Perfecting Your Pitch and Interview" workshop.

I really liked Kelly. Felicia sometimes talked over Kelly and dominated conversations. She also seems to stick to certain ways she think works and doesn't offer multifaceted views. For example, during one session, she implied that it was a negative be in a multidisciplinary field like SBS, at least in terms of trying to find an internship and to downplay it.
N/A
I am not sure who William Vance is and because I was only able to attend one session we were split into different groups with different instructors.
I am not sure who the listed instructor is. The professional skills seminars I attended were all led by Kelly and Felicia who are excellent at what they do.

good
Great.
Responsible, familiar with job search technique
William is a really experienced tutor, and he is patient in our questions and sharp in answering it. I enjoy his teaching.
Very good
I don't remember meeting this instructor.
no comment
Very well done.
The training sessions are very helpful.
Excellent instructor!

An effective instructor - explains things clearly.
I had no interactions with Mr. Vance.
Useful information to know when applying for internships, jobs, etc. I enjoyed that you could pick and choose which ones you want to go to.
- Attend as many events as possible, take them seriously, listen
So extremely useful! Whatever you think you are good at or don't need - think again! Way less boring than you would think.
Extremely helpful!
Choosing topics is very important. I learned a lot in my interested topics.
good
I would recommend these sessions to other students as they are extremely relevant and useful.

I would recommend this course. It teaches you very useful life skills that you'll always need. I thought I was good at interviews but this course taught me how I can be even better and what not to do.
Yes. It's useful and interesting.
Amazing. 10/10. would recommend.
It's required, some sessions are better than others.
This course is a foundation course. Useful!
Although it brings up relevant topics, a lot of the tips and tricks shared are common knowledge or things you can learn in the work environment.

Variety of professionally related topics that will help you prepare for a career in public health (applying to jobs, writing a cover letter, professional email etiquette, public speaking skills, etc.). I greatly appreciated the course structure and content. Many thanks!
Lame
I would not recommend this course unless if there is serious rework of how content is presented. I would rather have had multiple small group discussions.
I would recommend the public speaking seminar -- even if you feel you are a great speaker, this course provided useful tips for even the most confident people.
I would recommend.
It's important to take this because you can always learn new concepts on how to be a better professional.

I would definitely recommend this course to incoming or current students. It is a collection of small lectures on how to improve your skills in professional settings by working on your presentation both in person and on paper.
These sessions are very helpful for preparing for internships and overall professional integrity.

Definitely attend the seminars when you can. I would at least gain some skills in cover letter writing, resume writing, email writing, and interviewing before applying for an internship in the winter. Felicia is very helpful during the appointments, and she seems invested in the students' success. She definitely vouches for you and wants you to land a good position!
May be helpful for some, but not for older students who have had professional experience.
Yes
This course introduced the ethics in research and study, which would be very helpful in our career. I would recommend.

Professional Skills Seminar will provide various skills that you can choose from to enhance your career profile through resume building, social media, and public speaking which are all very useful when you are hunting for an internship or prospective job.
There is a broad array of topic areas that are covered, so it's guaranteed that you'll have the opportunity to attend a session that will be of use to you!
I would recommend - can learn a lot about professional skills and be able to choose which courses to attend.

I'd say it's a basic introduction to some professional skills. It's very useful if you've never held a job. It's not quite as useful if you have years of work/professional experience. I would recommend taking advantage of seminars covering skills you need to develop. I would not recommend it otherwise.
The professional skills series really help students prepare their career. I highly recommend this class.
could learn something and get help from the teachers about professional skills.
good
Yes. This professional skill series prepares students for the career development. very resourceful and helpful.
Great at teaching you skills you'll need to get by in a professional environment! And yes would recommend
Great course. Very practical and applicable skills for job hunting.
great class
I would recommend it, because it is useful for job search.
Definitely should not miss this course.
Helpful, necessary
Yes

required for YSPH (unfortunately) so yeah

I would recommend this course as it provides real world skills.
left with many skills, would recommend!
I recommend this class, which provided many useful tips for internship preparers like me.
This class covers useful job-hunting skills, such as resume/cover letter editing, networking, interview tips, etc. I will recommend it to another student.
This course helps students develop professional skills for interviews and public speaking. Would strongly recommend to another student.
Professional skills I believe is helpful for every student

The course is useful, more than anything. It prepares you well to find internships, jobs, and make connections. It gives you the tools you need to utilize what you learned here and market yourself adequately.

This course equips students with basic employment skills for beginning a professional career. I would recommend this course to students who do not have prior work experience, but I do not think it is at all useful for students who come from a professional background.
Introduction to and overview of basic skills required to be successful in today's job market
The Saturday sessions are very valuable but the other weekday sessions I attendeded were just okay, useful for a basic understanding but nothing beyond that.
I would recommend this course to students with no professional experience. It provides useful (if, in my opinion, somewhat rudimentary) tips on hiring practices.
If this course were not mandatory, I would not recommend it.
